speaker: Speaker 1
text: Have you ever wondered how Wall Street professionals consistently

speaker: Speaker 1
text: outperform year after year while retail traders do nothing but spin their wheels

speaker: Speaker 1
text: never gaining any traction? And while retail traders are scouring the internet to find a

speaker: Speaker 1
text: holy grail trading strategy, professional traders are laughing all the way to the bank

speaker: Speaker 1
text: because they understand they don't need a holy grail trading strategy to win.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Well in this video, I'm going to show you exactly how they're trading and how you can

speaker: Speaker 1
text: trade more like the pros and less like all the other retail traders.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: This video is going to completely shift the way you think about trading and how

speaker: Speaker 1
text: you approach the markets. Because it's not that retail traders can't win,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: they're just simply playing the wrong game. And you may be saying, well Adam,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: these trading firms outperform because they have better technology, faster execution,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: more data. And while that used to be true, it's just simply not the case anymore. The truth is,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: the game has completely changed. Today, retail traders have access to everything the pros do.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: We have access to the same data feeds. We have the same backtesting capabilities.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: We even have automated execution with smart order routing. Long story short,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: retail traders have everything they need to trade just like the top trading firms,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: except one thing. They just don't know how to put it together. It's purely just a knowledge gap.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: And in this video, I'm going to close that knowledge gap for you because there are three

speaker: Speaker 1
text: things top trading firms focus on. And once you understand these, you'll never look at

speaker: Speaker 1
text: trading the same way again. Let's dive into it. So what are these three things top firms focus on?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Well, the first one is the foundation of everything. And it's where most retail

speaker: Speaker 1
text: traders go wrong right out of the gate. Because while amateur traders are chasing returns,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: basically chasing their tail, professional traders have a completely different goal.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: So that brings me to point number one, to trade more like top trading firms,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: you must first understand the real goal of trading. You got to know what you're actually

speaker: Speaker 1
text: trying to achieve. And no, it is not just make as much money as possible. I mean, think about it.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: What is the goal of trading? Make money, right? Make as much money as possible. Okay, sure. But

description: A simple visual comparison of two “investments” (green vs black line) that start and end at the same point, used to force the viewer to admit that path/volatility matters even when total return is identical.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: what if I told you that's actually not the goal at all? That's simply just a side effect of chasing

speaker: Speaker 1
text: a different goal entirely. Let me show you what I mean. I want you to look at these two investments

speaker: Speaker 1
text: and tell me which one is better, green or black. Now, this one is pretty easy. I expect everyone

description: Continuation of the same two-line investment graphic, now used to land the conclusion: green is better because it’s the same return with more consistency; black implies stressful swings.
Same visual setup, but the narration pivots: it’s not just comfort—there’s a mathematical reason the smoother curve is superior, setting up the next example/question.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: watching this video to answer this correctly. Both of these investments start and end in the

speaker: Speaker 1
text: exact same place. So the return is identical, but clearly one of them is better. And if you answer

speaker: Speaker 1
text: green, that's correct. I think we can all intuitively make that conclusion, right? It's

speaker: Speaker 1
text: the exact same return, but with much more consistency. In the end, the investment represented

speaker: Speaker 1
text: by the black line achieved the same return, but probably at the cost of many sleepless nights,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: maybe a few gray hairs. But here's the thing. It's not just about sleeping better at night.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: What if I told you there's actually a mathematical reason why the green line is better? And I'll

speaker: Speaker 1
text: demonstrate this with a second question. Now, which one is better in this example,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: blue or orange? I'm like an optometrist. Which one is more clear? No, the orange line achieved a

description: A second comparison graphic (blue vs orange line) where one has higher return but higher volatility; used as a ‘test’ to separate amateur instincts from professional decision-making.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: lower return, but also with very little volatility. And the blue line achieved a bigger return,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: but obviously with more volatility. So which one would you choose? Now, most amateur traders

speaker: Speaker 1
text: watching this video right now are screaming at the screen saying blue, because duh, more money.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: But here's where the pros think differently. Most elite traders, even the aggressive ones who are

speaker: Speaker 1
text: shooting for the biggest return possible, would choose the orange line, hands down. And I'll tell

speaker: Speaker 1
text: you the reason. The reason is because in trading, you can always, in theory, add size, right? If

speaker: Speaker 1
text: you can achieve the orange line, you can add size to achieve the green line or add even more size to

speaker: Speaker 1
text: achieve the red line. Now I say in theory, because this assumes that returns don't diminish as you

speaker: Speaker 1
text: add size due to market impact. But as long as you're sticking to pretty liquid markets and not

speaker: Speaker 1
text: trading hundreds of millions of dollars, this is probably the least of your worries. The point is

speaker: Speaker 1
text: to trade more like the pros, you have to stop chasing returns and instead engineer the equity

speaker: Speaker 1
text: curve. Amateur traders chase the biggest return, pros engineer the shape of the return and then

speaker: Speaker 1
text: scale it. Now, hedge funds understand this. If you walk into a hedge fund and pitch them your

speaker: Speaker 1
text: strategy, the last thing they're going to ask is what's your return. They're going to ask about

speaker: Speaker 1
text: things like your risk management. They're going to ask for a few metrics, like your Sharpe ratio,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: your Sortino ratio, things that measure portfolio volatility. And you may be sitting there like,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: why are they not asking about my returns? Because they know those metrics are where they need to be.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: They can kind of create whatever return profile they want. Now, obviously, this is some high

speaker: Speaker 1
text: level stuff. So you may be thinking, well, how are we going to design a trading strategy like this?

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Well, first, let me tell you how we're definitely not going to do it. We're not going to do this by

speaker: Speaker 1
text: trading one single trading strategy, even if it's a really good one. There just isn't a single trading

speaker: Speaker 1
text: strategy that will achieve this, at least not for any significant amount of time. If a single strategy

speaker: Speaker 1
text: does look like this for a year or two, it usually has something really ugly under the hood. I'm

speaker: Speaker 1
text: talking about ticking time bomb strategies, things like Forex, Martingale, things that look really

speaker: Speaker 1
text: great until they don't. Now, that's a topic for another video. But the point is no single strategy

speaker: Speaker 1
text: is going to get you this consistent, scalable equity curve over the long run. No single strategy

speaker: Speaker 1
text: is going to give you truly asymmetrical risk adjusted returns. There is no holy grail trading

speaker: Speaker 1
text: strategy. Pros understand this, and that's why professionals prioritize portfolio construction

speaker: Speaker 1
text: over individual strategies. And more specifically, they build what we call an ensemble portfolio.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: This is the real holy grail, in my opinion. Let me show you how this is done in the real world.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Now, here you can see two trading systems simulated over the past three and a half years.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Strategy A is the blue line and strategy B is the red line. Which one of these is better? I want

speaker: Speaker 1
text: you to answer this one last question. Both of them achieved the exact same return. They have a very

speaker: Speaker 1
text: similar Sharpe ratio and a very similar volatility of the returns, but clearly they are inversely

speaker: Speaker 1
text: correlated, right? When one zigs, the other zags. Now, you could argue that red is better because

speaker: Speaker 1
text: technically it does have a smaller max drawdown, but I'd argue it's minimal and could be due to

speaker: Speaker 1
text: just the sequence of returns. And even if it is a little better, I'm going to show you what's

speaker: Speaker 1
text: better than both of these. How about instead of choosing one, we just combine them and run both,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: right? So instead of allocating $30,000 to one of them, what if we just cut the size in half and run

speaker: Speaker 1
text: on each of them? So still a total allocation of $30,000, but split between them. And you can see

speaker: Speaker 1
text: what this looks like with the purple line. Now, this is actually one of the systems we're running

speaker: Speaker 1
text: in our fund. Obviously we'd be insane to share exact specifics of it in a public video on YouTube.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: I'm sure you can understand that, but if you do want to know exactly what the strategy is,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: I'm going to tell you at the end of the video, how to access it. Now, aside from having a clearly

speaker: Speaker 1
text: more stable equity curve, when you look at the chart, you can also see the other metrics here.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: The Marr ratio is significantly higher. By the way, Marr ratio just simply means the,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: it's the annualized return divided by the max drawdown. So the higher this number, the better

speaker: Speaker 1
text: the sharp is also significantly better. And the volatility is much lower. Now, again,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: the point of this video is not to confuse you with any math or anything, but the point is,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: you can see that now that we have a smoother return with less volatility, now we have a

speaker: Speaker 1
text: strategy we can scale. And the average capital required of each of these trades is actually

speaker: Speaker 1
text: way smaller than the capital we're allocating. So what if we just add size, right? You can see

speaker: Speaker 1
text: what that might look like. If we add 2X size or 3X size, you can see how this can start adding up

speaker: Speaker 1
text: to some nicer returns. All right, cool. Now you could run this strategy. It's a pretty good one,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: but what if it stops performing? Professional traders would never have a single point of failure

speaker: Speaker 1
text: in their portfolios. So we don't stop here. For wall street pros, one or two strategies isn't

speaker: Speaker 1
text: enough. In fact, here's a simulation of the strategies we're currently running in our Skyview

speaker: Speaker 1
text: portfolio, but how do we get here, right? Like what is this portfolio? Well, as you probably

speaker: Speaker 1
text: guessed, this is an ensemble portfolio made up of several trading strategies. And you can clearly

speaker: Speaker 1
text: see each of the individual strategies are much more volatile than the portfolio itself. But when

speaker: Speaker 1
text: you blend them together, we get exactly what we're looking for. But let's start from scratch. You can

speaker: Speaker 1
text: see on the left side, we have 10 trading strategies and we already have one of them turned on. Now,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: this first one is a great strategy. It's got a very robust edge. And if we were running our

speaker: Speaker 1
text: whole portfolio on it, you can see we'd have achieved around a 15.8% annualized return with

speaker: Speaker 1
text: a max drawdown of 14.4%. So at least it made money. But I don't think any of us would be

speaker: Speaker 1
text: thrilled with that. Not exactly a hedge fund grade equity curve here. But let me show you

speaker: Speaker 1
text: what happens when we turn each of these trading systems on. And these aren't just 10 random trading

speaker: Speaker 1
text: systems, by the way, these have all been meticulously designed to complement each other

speaker: Speaker 1
text: and work together. And I'll show you some real trading action soon. But hang with me here. You

speaker: Speaker 1
text: can see as we turn each of these trading systems on, the portfolio really starts to smooth out

speaker: Speaker 1
text: and scale. Now, we're only four strategies in, but you can see the total portfolio has a higher

speaker: Speaker 1
text: return and a lower drawdown than each of the four strategies have by themselves. So significantly

speaker: Speaker 1
text: better already. Now let's keep going. Now you can start to see how much better the portfolio looks.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Remember, in the earlier example, I showed you how combining those two strategies,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: we were able to achieve a mar ratio of 3.4. Well, you can see this portfolio has a mar ratio of 13.1.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: And you can see the mar ratio of each individual strategy is nowhere close to that. Guys,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: think about how powerful this is. Not only have we significantly improved our portfolio,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: but we've also reduced our reliance on a single trading system. So if one of these trading systems

speaker: Speaker 1
text: starts to degrade in performance, we have nine others to lean on. Now, they certainly could

speaker: Speaker 1
text: start to degrade in performance all at the same time. That's called clustering. But we've

speaker: Speaker 1
text: significantly reduced our risk of that. Amateur traders are scouring the internet to find one

speaker: Speaker 1
text: good strategy. And when a strategy doesn't get them to where they want to go, they move on and

speaker: Speaker 1
text: search for the next Holy Grail. Pros understand that proper portfolio construction and efficient

speaker: Speaker 1
text: use of capital is the real Holy Grail. And I want to read you a quote from one of my favorite books,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: Advances in Financial Machine Learning by Dr. Marcus Lopez de Prado. He says,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: amateurs develop individual strategies, believing there is such a thing as a magical formula for

speaker: Speaker 1
text: riches. In contrast, professionals develop methods to mass produce strategies. The money is not in

speaker: Speaker 1
text: making a car, it is in making a car factory. And that's what the pros do. They build the factory.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: They put trading strategies through an assembly line. They build methods to formulate, scale,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: and monitor strategies. And if needed, retire them. With each strategy, they crawl, walk,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: then run. And typically they run them until they break. And they have methods in place to

speaker: Speaker 1
text: monitor and identify if they break. We often talk about trading as a business. This is what that

speaker: Speaker 1
text: means. Now I'm about to show you a glimpse into our trading account and share with you the missing

speaker: Speaker 1
text: piece that ties all of this together. Because understanding this next piece is really what

speaker: Speaker 1
text: separates the amateurs from the pros. But before we do that, let's reinforce what you've learned

speaker: Speaker 1
text: up to this point. First pros utilize an ensemble portfolio approach, a collection of truly

speaker: Speaker 1
text: uncorrelated and inversely correlated trading systems blended into one portfolio. Each system

speaker: Speaker 1
text: is built to serve a specific purpose and fill in the weaknesses of the others. So the whole becomes

speaker: Speaker 1
text: greater than the sum of its parts. Now you've probably heard the phrase diversification is the

speaker: Speaker 1
text: only free lunch in investing. Well, this is true diversification, and this is how the pros reduce

speaker: Speaker 1
text: volatility, manage risk, and scale with confidence. Now check this out. I'm going to show you some

speaker: Speaker 1
text: real money trades from our smaller portfolio. So on this day, you can see we had five algorithmic

speaker: Speaker 1
text: trading systems running, each one designed to approach the market differently. You can see the

speaker: Speaker 1
text: first trade of the day fired near the market open. Now this is a short volatility trade that works

speaker: Speaker 1
text: best in choppy or mean reverting markets, but you can see clearly that's not what we got on this day.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: The market actually trended hard to the downside, selling off by more than 100 points, and we got

speaker: Speaker 1
text: stopped out on the downside of this trade. But you can see while this was going on, our zero DTE wave

speaker: Speaker 1
text: system spotted the early weakness and immediately started placing bearish trades with the trend. So

speaker: Speaker 1
text: we've got a mean reverting strategy combined with a bearish trend following strategy. And obviously

speaker: Speaker 1
text: this worked out nicely because the profits from this system really helped to cushion the blow from

speaker: Speaker 1
text: the losses on the first trade. Now fast forward to the end of the trading day as the market bottomed

speaker: Speaker 1
text: and showed signs of strength, our power hour system started putting unused capital to work

speaker: Speaker 1
text: with some bullish trades. In fact, these power hour trades tied up zero additional capital because we

speaker: Speaker 1
text: were able to margin them against the bearish trades we were already in. So we're basically

speaker: Speaker 1
text: squeezing all the juice out of this trading day that we possibly can. And at the end of the day,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: even though this first trade lost money, we barely felt it. And that's exactly the point, guys. Three

speaker: Speaker 1
text: out of five of these systems traded on this day, but they aren't just three random strategies,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: right? Each of these strategies were designed to fill in the gaps and fill in the weaknesses of

speaker: Speaker 1
text: each other. They're built to serve a specific purpose in the portfolio. And I'll show you just

speaker: Speaker 1
text: one more trading day to really drive this home. You can see this day started out by firing our

speaker: Speaker 1
text: zero DTE range trade again, but with much better success this time, as you can see, it did turn out

speaker: Speaker 1
text: to be a very choppy and mean reverting day. Now, the idea of the ensemble portfolio system goes

speaker: Speaker 1
text: beyond just running multiple systems, right? You can actually practice this ensemble approach

speaker: Speaker 1
text: within each system itself. And you can see this by looking at our zero DTE green day system.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: This green day strategy didn't just take one shot. In fact, it entered in tranches scaling into the

speaker: Speaker 1
text: move throughout the day and diversifying by entry time to spread out our risk and remove timing from

speaker: Speaker 1
text: the equation. So not only can you diversify by strategy, you can also diversify by time

speaker: Speaker 1
text: within a strategy itself. And you can clearly see this with green day, how one entry stopped

speaker: Speaker 1
text: out on this down move, but green day overall made money on this day. All right, cool. So we

speaker: Speaker 1
text: have an ensemble portfolio of trading systems working beautifully, but there's another problem

speaker: Speaker 1
text: and it's kind of a big one. The problem is trading all these systems manually is nearly

speaker: Speaker 1
text: an impossible task. You're talking about five systems, each with different rules, timeframes,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: entries and exits. It would be like trying to play five games of chess at once, each with its own

speaker: Speaker 1
text: board timer and different opponent. And you're expected to make the right move on every single

speaker: Speaker 1
text: one of them in real time. And the fact is most people don't have seven hours a day to sit and

speaker: Speaker 1
text: stare at the markets between your job, your family, trying to live life. It would be impossible

speaker: Speaker 1
text: to keep up with these systems. So how are we going to trade all of these systems? Well, you've got

speaker: Speaker 1
text: three options. Option one is quit your job and trade them manually. Aside from the fact that

speaker: Speaker 1
text: this would be emotional torture, unless you're a robot, it's just a recipe for disaster. Humans are

speaker: Speaker 1
text: slow. We hesitate. We overthink. Even the most disciplined traders fall victim to fear, greed,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: or overconfidence. So it's just not efficient. Now option two is hire a team of traders to manage

speaker: Speaker 1
text: each system individually. Now this is actually what the big hedge funds used to do. The top

speaker: Speaker 1
text: portfolio managers never placed the trades themselves. Instead, they kept a high level view

speaker: Speaker 1
text: and stayed focused on the bigger picture. But unless you've got $50 million in capital, this

description: Screen recording of a trading account/dashboard alongside (or within) an automation/execution software interface. It’s used as proof-of-work to make the automation claim feel real: market trending up, system firing bullish trades, profits visible.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: option is probably off the table. Option three is use technology to automate your trading. And this

speaker: Speaker 1
text: is exactly what we do. It's pretty much what all the pro traders nowadays are doing. Automation

description: Same screen-based proof segment: trading account P&L and recent trades visible while he narrates hedge-fund workflow vs retail constraints. The visual reinforces ‘this is running without me’ and ‘profits are happening.’

speaker: Speaker 1
text: allows us to easily run all of these systems in parallel flawlessly while we go on with our lives.

description: Continued platform/account view while he pivots from ‘proof’ to ‘I won’t share specifics on YouTube.’ The screen acts as a teaser: enough to imply legitimacy, not enough to replicate.

Same screen segment; the visual remains a trading dashboard while the narration continues the ‘hedge funds do this / retail can’t’ framing and the automation pitch. It functions as ongoing credibility wallpaper rather than instructional content.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: And I'll show you exactly what this looks like. You're looking at my trading account right here

speaker: Speaker 1
text: and also the software we use to execute our strategies. You see the market has been trending

description: Trading account/software still on screen as he explicitly transitions into community/offer language. The platform view continues to imply ‘real trading happening’ while he sets up the next funnel step.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: up all day and our strategies have been riding this trend by firing off some bullish trades.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: And you see we got some nice profits here. Now, obviously daily P&L doesn't really matter. It's

speaker: Speaker 1
text: not really something we even look at. But some of you guys have been asking about my performance

speaker: Speaker 1
text: and also about my strategies. And I'm definitely not going to share all the specifics in a YouTube

speaker: Speaker 1
text: video. I'm sure you can understand. We did decide to open up a small community and share some of

speaker: Speaker 1
text: what we're doing behind the scenes. You can see some of our trading performance and follow it in

speaker: Speaker 1
text: real time. It's a fun place to be and a really valuable place to improve your trading. I'm

speaker: Speaker 1
text: extremely bullish on everything we're doing. And if you want to get involved, be sure to check that

speaker: Speaker 1
text: out. There's a link in the description. And you can see these trades firing off as I speak. But

speaker: Speaker 1
text: how cool is this, guys? I'm able to do my job. I'm able to record this video, serve our community,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: research and develop trading strategies. These are all high ROI activities. And obviously,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: my job is trading. But the act of actually staring at a screen stressed out while you place these

speaker: Speaker 1
text: trades manually is a zero ROI activity. And technology is better at it anyways. I'd much

speaker: Speaker 1
text: rather spend my time on high ROI activities and actually enjoying life, serving our community

speaker: Speaker 1
text: and not wasting my time mind numbingly watching the markets. And I know that's fun for some

speaker: Speaker 1
text: traders, but we don't trade for fun. Pros don't trade for fun. We trade to make money. We don't

speaker: Speaker 1
text: do it to cure boredom or to satisfy a gambling addiction. Again, pros don't trade for those

speaker: Speaker 1
text: reasons. And guys, so much of trading is mental. But so many mental game issues get solved when

speaker: Speaker 1
text: you automate your trading and when you just stop staring at the market all day. I myself had tens

speaker: Speaker 1
text: of thousands of trades under my belt. And before we started automating 100% of our trading, even I

speaker: Speaker 1
text: was guilty of overthinking trades and even letting whatever I saw on the internet or TV that day sway

speaker: Speaker 1
text: my trading style. And something most traders forget, if all your testing assumes perfect

speaker: Speaker 1
text: execution and no human error, but then you're trading manually, there's no way your live results

speaker: Speaker 1
text: are ever going to match up. And this is why if you want to trade like the pros, you need to

speaker: Speaker 1
text: leverage automation to execute and scale your ensemble portfolio. Automation handles execution

speaker: Speaker 1
text: with precision and helps to remove emotion. This means no more overthinking every trade

speaker: Speaker 1
text: and no more missing trades because you were stuck in a meeting or got a phone call. Automation also

speaker: Speaker 1
text: allows you to stop staring at every tick of the market. Guys, I cannot stress enough how valuable

speaker: Speaker 1
text: this is for your mental game. It's important to disconnect from that noise and instead maintain a

speaker: Speaker 1
text: top-down view, a high-level view of your portfolio, just like the hedge funds have always done by

speaker: Speaker 1
text: hiring traders. And it's kind of like autopilot for your portfolio, right? Safer, smoother, and

speaker: Speaker 1
text: more precise. And just like flying an airplane, autopilot doesn't mean the pilot should necessarily

speaker: Speaker 1
text: tune out and fall asleep, but it does help you be a better and safer pilot. As you can see, if you

speaker: Speaker 1
text: want any real consistency with your trading, you need to take this journey seriously and give it

speaker: Speaker 1
text: the respect it deserves. You need to treat trading like a business, not a hobby, because otherwise

speaker: Speaker 1
text: you're going to be competing against people who are dedicating our lives to this. Now guys, we're on

speaker: Speaker 1
text: a mission to become the top trading resource on YouTube because in a world full of fake gurus and

speaker: Speaker 1
text: empty promises, we feel like it's more important than ever to show you guys what real trading looks

speaker: Speaker 1
text: like. And we're going to be pulling back the curtain. So if you found this video helpful,

speaker: Speaker 1
text: be sure to drop a like, hit the subscribe button. We've got a lot more videos in the works. You're

speaker: Speaker 1
text: not going to want to miss them. And if you want to go deeper and see more behind the scenes of

speaker: Speaker 1
text: what we're doing, again, we can't share everything on YouTube, but we did open up a small private

speaker: Speaker 1
text: community links in the description. So thanks again for watching. Hope you found this valuable.

speaker: Speaker 1
text: I'll see you in the next one.
